p.s: In the following text I am going to analyze William Shakespeare's Sonnet 65 with a focus at the language and stylistic devices.
The sun it was written in the Elizabethan time and has from line one to 12 a ABAB rhyme-scheme and from line 13 to 14 AA system like the most most of Shakespeare's sonnets.
Line one starts with aan enumeration where William Shakespeare lists the natural things that are loosinglosing their power (l. 2), which is a personification.
He defines the named things from line one as mortality (l. 2) which means that all flowers and trees losing their livelife through winter season.
From line three up to line five are three different rethoricalrhetorical questions.
FirsteFirst he asks why the beautiness of summer/fall season has to go away (l. 3) and can't stay through the whole winter until spring.
You can answer this question very easily because everyone knows that it is totoo cold for the flowers.
After that he asks whose action is no stronger than a flower (l. 4) which is at the same time metaphor.
He means the snow which covers everything and sometimes kills flowers with that high press.
The honey breath of summer seems to be very important for him (l. 5).
He wants to know why the smell cannot stay the whole time until it is summer again.
After that he names the winter as wrackful siege of batt'ring days (l. 6) which describes the rainy and snowy days in winter season.
It is a metaphor for the depressing feeling of cold weather in the very early darkness outside.
Line 7 and eight is a connected metaphor where Shakespeare cars big hard rocks as a gate of steel (l. 8) which means that the winter just blocks fall and spring season and cannot be skipped.
He wants the time to decay (l. 8) because his personal impressions from line one up to line eight are not that good.
Following he tells what he doesn't like during that time: the meditation (l. 9) in general.
He defines the following spring season as a jewel (l. 10) and asks why it is hidden behind the winter season.
He asks again who can stop the seasonal change (l. 11f.) and who can see you the plants from spoiling.

Shakespeare used a lot of stylistic devices to describe his own impressions and feelings of the winter season.
He remembers in the sonnet to a couple of his favourite things in the earlier seasons to show what he is excited for after winter.
